citation.article-title: Description of a new species of mucilaginous bacteria, Bacillus edaphicus sp. nov., and confirmation of the taxonomic status of Bacillus mucilaginosus Avakyan et al. 1986 based on data from phenotypic and genotypic analysis.

p.s: Description of Bacillus edaphicus sp. nov.
Bacillus edaphicus (L. adj. edaphicus, living in soil)
On synthetic media with carbohydrates and devoid of nitrogen sources, the colonies are mucous, transparent, convex, 0.8-2.0 cm in diameter, with an even edge and smooth surface.
On potato agar and synthetic media with carbohydrates and ammonium nitrogen, the colonies are light, flat, raised in the center, round, smooth, moist, even-edged, up to 0.5 mm in diameter.
No growth occurs on nutrient agar or nutrient broth.
Cells are nonmotile regular rods, 1.0-1.5 x 4-10 μm in size.
Cells grown on media with carbohydrates in the absence of nitrogen sources are surrounded by mucous capsules 7-12 μm thick.
On media containing ammonium nitrogen, ellipsoidal endospores (1-1.2 x 1.7-2.0 μm) are formed with eight to ten ridge-like protrusions.
The cell wall structure is of the gram-positive type.
Palmitic, anteisopentadecanoic, and stearic acids are most frequent in the cellular lipids.
The temperature interval suitable for growth is 7-45°C.
Cells are resistant to lysozyme, chemoorganotrophic, catalase-positive, and incapable of glucose fermentation or nitrate reduction.
Sugars and polyols are utilized as the sources of carbon and energy.
The G+C content of DNA is 54.6-56.5 mol %.
